id: Spanish - Introductory 1-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Spanish - Introductory 1
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Spanish - Introductory 1
By the end of the course, you'll: 
• Have developed some ability to express yourself in basic Spanish
• Have some ability to use correctly the present, past and "going to" tenses
• Have some understanding of how adjectives, my-mine, and the verb tener are used
• Have practised the difference between ser/estar and have some ability to use them correctly
• Have practised, with some success, the use of numbers and telling the time
• Have begun to develop some basic working Spanish vocabulary 
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: French - Introductory 1-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: French - Introductory 1
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
French - Introductory 1
By the end of the course, you'll be able to: 
• Greet people and introduce yourself (and others) at a basic level
• Use expressions for basic everyday communication
• Ask and answer questions about people’s names, nationalities, family, work situation, likes and dislikes (both formal and informal)
• Describe and use the rules of pronunciation (including the alphabet)
• Understand and use some basic French grammar: the verbs avoir and être, the present tense of a few verbs in -er, articles (definite and indefinite), singular/plural and masculine/feminine of nouns and nationality adjectives, possessive adjectives
• Order, offer, accept and refuse food and drink in a café at a basic level
• Become more familiar with the cultural aspects related to these topics 
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Communication English - Level 2-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Communication English - Level 2
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Communication English - Level 2
For those who can understand and use simple English in everyday situations but need to build confidence, vocabulary and grammar. 
By the end of the course, you'll:
• Feel more confident speaking English in everyday situations
• Be able to write more correct sentences
• Be able to understand more English, especially “New Zealand English”
• Have increased your vocabulary
• Be able to describe more about living in New Zealand and New Zealand culture
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents but to enrol you must contact the CEC office (04 385 8919) for an interview. There are limited free places available and you may need to go on a waiting list.  
There may be some places on the course for people who are not NZ residents or citizens but you must pay the course fee of $999. 
This course is subsidised by the Tertiary Education Commission and you must provide evidence of your NZ residency or citizenship (if applicable).
Please note that there is no student parking at the High School during the day. 
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

name: Te Reo Māori - Introductory 2
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 2
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to: 
• Discuss our responsibilities as a bi-cultural nation under ‘Te Tiriti o Waitangi’ and identify underlying Māori values such as: whanaungatanga, pepehā and tikanga
• Discuss the significance of whakapapa as a fundamental Māori world view and confidently describe your family and relationships through this lens

• Discuss protocol on the marae
• Recognise the importance and use of karakia and be able to recite one correctly
• Recognise the cultural values inherent within different whakataukī (proverbs) and kīwaha (idioms) and be able to correctly recite one of each

English in the Community: Johnsonville - Beginners+ (ESOL Level 1-2)
English in the Community courses help you to learn more English, get to know your community and meet new people. The groups aim to help you use what you already know, learn more from your tutor and the other students and feel more at home in your local community. 
To enrol in these courses, please contact the CEC office on 04 385 8919 or cec@whs.school.nz.
By the end of the course, you will: 
• Feel more confident speaking English in everyday situations 
• Be able to understand more English 
• Have learned new words and basic grammar
• Know more about living in New Zealand and your local community
The courses are free for NZ residents and citizens. The course fee for non-residents is $149.

id: Creative Writing - From Idea to Page-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Creative Writing - From Idea to Page
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Creative Writing - From Idea to Page
“Just write!”
That’s the advice given to every newbie writer… but what happens when you
struggle to get words on the page?
In this one-day course, we’ll brainstorm ideas, complete writing exercises and
discuss strategies for keeping up writing momentum.
Please bring pen and paper.  Tea and coffee available for your breaks, please bring lunch and any snacks you may need.  
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

id: Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images
Elevate your photography from ordinary to extraordinary and ensure your work stands out in the digital age. Creating captivating photographs and understanding what makes a photograph engaging is something every photographer should master. Camera settings are essential, but once you know them, you need to learn how to take photographs that stir emotions, impact your audience, and leave a lasting impression. After all, isn’t that the true purpose of photography? People don’t want to see the same landscapes or flowers they’ve seen thousands of times. But how do you turn what you love into something that makes people go, "Wow"?
 Captivation in photography means stopping a viewer in their tracks, making them look, feel, and connect. It’s about delivering a photograph that enthrals, evokes profound emotions, and shifts perspectives.
In a world brimming with images, only a few have the power to truly captivate and linger in our memories.
 This pioneering course is your gateway to mastering the art of creating captivating photographs at a time when AI-generated images are saturating our visual landscape. Create something genuine and memorable—images that spark curiosity, evoke emotions, and inspire changes in perception. It's time to define your unique style, refine your vision, and make your mark.
 Course Outcomes
 By the end of the five-week course, you’ll be able to: 
Identify the foundational elements that transform an ordinary image into a captivating one.
Create photographs that make people say "Wow" by applying techniques that add a spark of wonder to your shots.
Infuse your photographs with curiosity, making each frame a source of intrigue and interest.
Understand why some images linger in memory and how to make your photographs unforgettable.
Develop a unique style and vision that sets your work apart in the crowded digital landscape.

You will also learn skills and techniques to continue making journals as a mindful activity, for crafting with friends, or to make a gift for someone that is tailored to include the things they love!

id: Calligratherapy - Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Calligratherapy - Beginners
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Calligratherapy - Beginners
Many of us live sedentary lifestyles, sitting for up to eight hours or more a day hunched over our keyboard - all the while rarely taking a proper breath! Even if we wanted to take a deep enriching breath into the lower lobes of our lungs, we are limited due to our posture. Often due to the stresses and strains of a busy work and life balance, our unconscious brain can develop a pattern of holding, irregular and shadow breaths.
Does this sound like your experience? 
Not being able to breathe properly is the key cause of many chronic respiratory diseases (Nestor, 2020)
Calligratherapy combines science journalist James Nestor's theory on proper breathing with the philosophy of ancient Chinese calligraphy to promote a state of optimal wellbeing.
Calligratherapy has been developed specifically for those who have never practiced calligraphy before and who are interested in deriving the benefits without having to learn the language or all the characters. It integrates the simple and intuitive act of inhaling and exhaling into calligraphy practice with Eastern philosophy behind it.
A range of different breathing exercises are embedded into each 90 minute session focusing on different calligraphy scripts.  Over the five weeks, you will develop and practice the awareness of healthy breathing, while learning new techniques of Chinese soft brush calligraphy covering five different scripts. 
All materials included in course fee.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Start a new creative practice in Chinese soft brush calligraphy
Develop your own mindfulness strategy
Better manage everyday stress levels and access a calm, empowered and positive state of mind
Find ways to explore eastern philosophy and develop deeper connections with your spiritual self.

You will be introduced to a range of techniques and approaches such as cut and paste photos and text, collage and drawing on paper.

id: Oil Painting Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Oil Painting Workshop
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Oil Painting Workshop
In this course we will learn about painting with oils: one of the oldest and most interesting mediums, and one which has an undeserved reputation for being slow or intimidating! By the end of this workshop you will find it to be a forgiving, easy, and even quick medium to create beautiful art with.
In this workshop we will learn some quick methods for getting started in oils, using “alla prima” (wet on wet) methods to develop an understanding of the painting process. In addition to learning about the practical side of the medium, there will also be opportunities to learn a bit about the extraordinary history of painting in oils.
Most materials included in course fee - you will need to bring your own bristle brushes and an idea for your painting.  Basic paint colours provided, you're welcome to bring along any that you may already have at home.  Please wear clothing suitable for working in a messy environment, and prepare a means of transporting your wet painting home.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
- Paint pictures quickly using ‘alla prima’ methods.
- Effectively prepare a surface for painting.
- Prepare some basic colour mixes and methods of creating tone and contrast.
- Develop transparent glazes and washes over your painting.
- Recognise the difference between pigment, binder, solvent etc.
- Discuss the extensive history of painting methods

name: Zentangle® Method - Beginners
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Zentangle® Method - Beginners
The Zentangle® method is an easy-to-learn, relaxing and fun method to create amazing images by drawing structured patterns.
In this course you will learn to make beautiful art, following the 8 steps of the Zentangle® method from a certified Zentangle teacher.
Discover your creative side, even if you think you don’t have one. You might surprise yourself!  If you can hold a pen, you can do this.
Creating Zentangle patterns is super relaxing and a creative form of mindfulness. Increase your awareness and focus, get absorbed and feel more confident while making your own unique and original art.
Learn about borders, strings, and shading. Learn your first tangles and discover the world of Crescent Moon, Hollibaugh, Printemps, and Florz. It feels great to have creativity flowing. Anything is possible one stroke at a time. There are no mistakes to make here!
After a step-by-step introduction you will take home your amazing images and have discovered a new way to relax.
All art materials are included in course fee.  Tea and coffee is available but please bring your lunch/snacks.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-    follow the 8 steps of the Zentangle® method.
-    make beautiful structured black and white drawings.
-    explain why creating Zentangle patterns is a relaxing form of creative mindfulness.

id: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives
There is a widespread ‘lack of confidence’ epidemic among creatives, and if you have ever felt like your work is not good enough, hesitated to submit your art to competitions, or doubted your skills when applying for creative jobs, you are not alone! Creatives often feel imposter syndrome most acutely. Unlike other industries, those in the creative field produce something new every time, and sharing this with the world can be daunting, even for established artists.
 This pervasive self-doubt, known as imposter syndrome, affects countless artists and creators, often holding them back from realising their full potential. This concise workshop is designed to help you uncover the roots of this inner voice of insecurity and provide you with effective tools to overcome it. Through engaging activities and practical exercises, you will learn how to transform self-doubt into a source of strength, empowering you to confidently share your unique talents with the world.
 What you won't find in this masterclass: This is not a session about general self-growth or self-confidence, and it does not include positive affirmations or self-talk. All the information provided is based on scientific research and is applicable to all creative sectors.
Bring along some examples of your work on the day (eg a painting, a photograph of your work, etc).
 By the end of this workshop, you’ll be able to: 
Identify and challenge the origins of your imposter syndrome.
Apply practical techniques to silence your inner critic.
Share your creative work with increased confidence.
Turn self-doubt into a motivational tool.
Recognise and celebrate your achievements as a creative professional.

During this hands-on workshop, you’ll be guided through each step of the cheesemaking process while making your very own round of farmhouse style cheddar.
The fee includes a cheese press (value $95.00) which can be used every time you want to make a hard cheese. It holds up to 6 litres of milk and this is what you’ll be taking your cheese home in to press for 12 hours after the workshop. All ingredients, recipes and a full set of course notes are provided.
You’ll also receive comprehensive instruction on how to wax (if you choose to) and then mature your cheese over the next five weeks. Alexis will also demonstrate how to make halloumi cheese which will then be grilled for you to enjoy! There’ll be a short lunch break and cheese making supplies such as wax will be available to purchase.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
• Describe the basics of sanitisation and hygiene
• Recognise the difference between raw and pasteurised milk and know where to source them
• Make a round of cheddar cheese using a cheese press

• Describe how to make halloumi, following a demonstration

id: Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Put in the hard work on this one day Saturday workshop and experience the benefits of self-knowledge. Let the emotional knowledge you gain inform not only how you live your life but also how you feel about living it. You’ll be asking the big questions about not only how you live your life, but also why. Discover the tools and scientifically based information to inform the exploration of your life’s purpose.
Consider your emotional needs and how they relate to personal meaning. You’ll unwrap the concepts of emotional nutrition and be shown how to be guided by your values and start to think of them as a compass directing the journey of your life. To do this you’ll identify your values hierarchy and learn about how this framework can inform how you live your life. Once you can apply a spirit of consistency to your self-identified larger purpose, as well as your needs, then your life’s purpose, emotional needs and core values, will align. It’s quite a transformational day!
Bring pen and paper.  Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch/snacks.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Develop a Life Purpose Statement
Perform an Emotional Needs Self-Assessment
Elicit Your Core Values
Align your goals with your life purpose, emotional needs and core values

Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you - then learn how to knit in the English style.

venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Garden Planting Design
Spent a fortune on plants and still not achieved the dream? Can’t work out why some plants thrive and others barely survive? Ready to make exciting changes but no idea where to start and not much gardening background? This interactive and fun course will answer all your queries and give you confidence to create the garden you want with the right plants to achieve it. Style of garden, colour, plant palette – we’ll cover it all – and more.

Time permitting, we will look at photos of your gardens as “personal case studies” to help you get the most from the course.
After completing the course, you will have created a detailed hand drawn plant design that will be your blue print for the next steps… planting up!
 
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to: 
•Identify the style of your dream garden and learn what plants will best achieve this and guarantee success
• Identify and work with the site and climate conditions of your garden/outdoor areas to be developed; modify plant choices if necessary
• Accurately draw your detailed planting design on paper and to scale.
• Understand the role of colour and different plants in the garden and incorporate it into your design
• Learn how to improve your soil to guarantee success
• Use your final design to create a “shopping list” of plants
• Calculate anticipated expenditure / prepare a budget (to also include soil improving items)
 
Please note that this course DOES NOT include:
 
Hardscaping design. This is available in a separate course.
 
• Planting up your garden
• Recommending suppliers, service providers and retailers, although knowledge and experiences of the tutor and peers will be shared appropriately
• Pruning practices or plant disease management
• Organic methods of practice, although knowledge and experiences of the tutor and peers will be shared appropriately
• In depth coverage of specific plant groups eg roses, vegetables
Please bring some scrap paper, a notebook, pens, pencils and an eraser.

description:
Pelvic Power Workshop
Apart from assisting with supporting internal organs, and controlling elimination, the pelvic floor is an important part of a woman's overall stability and posture, so you will gain improvement in this respect as well. You'll learn far more than conventional pelvic floor strengthening. 
You'll learn to differentiate different parts of the pelvic floor, and also how the pelvic floor functions in conjunction with breathing and spinal movements.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
• Recognise the anatomy of the pelvic floor, where the muscles are and how they work
• Coordinate the pelvic floor muscles with breathing, and with the spine, and recognise its role in overall good posture
• Discover what habits you have which work against your pelvic floor muscles working well
• Practise exercises designed to help you rehabilitate and strengthen your pelvic floor
Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required. For women only.

id: Genealogy - Basics of ancestry.com DNA tests-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Genealogy - Basics of ancestry.com DNA tests
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Genealogy - Basics of ancestry.com DNA tests
Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is?  Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.
We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this.  We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.
Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.
Please note:  this course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com  All computer courses are run in the school computer labs and you are required to use the school desktops for the duration of the course (you are not able to use your own laptop).  Some of the courses may require you to login onto the network. 
Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.
 By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-  Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
-  Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
-  Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
-  Understand where to find other tools
-  Understand the options for using other DNA websites
-  Understand where to get further help
 Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

id: Financial Planning for Retirement-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Financial Planning for Retirement
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Financial Planning for Retirement
Massey University's annual Retirement Expenditure Guidelines study (2019) found:
Just 40% of pre-retirees believed they were well-prepared for retirement, and 57% considered retirement to be a concern.  They also confirmed, New Zealand Superannuation is not sufficient to fund the retirement most people want.
Ministry of Social Development (2020):
22% of all people receiving New Zealand Superannuation also receive additional support payments, with over 44,000 superannuants receiving additional accommodation support,
And if you needed to obtain Government assisted accommodation, at the end of March 2020, more than 16,300 households were waiting for state or social housing.
Living in a motel or boarding house with strangers (who may have other vulnerable backgrounds) is not an ideal or safe location to spend your retirement years.   But for many, it is the only option they can afford.
If you have not planned for your retirement, then this course is you! 
This course has been developed for people in their 50’s or 60’s that are looking at retirement and have no idea if they can financially survive it: what to do, what $’s they need, how or where they can generate additional income, or even where to go to get help. 
It is targeted towards those that still have some time (for some - not much) to make adjustments, learn some basic financial skills, make some big decisions, and positively influence the quality of their pending retirement. 
You will be introduced to a simple step by step guide to developing a financial plan for retirement. 
You will work though a case study in class, and can then go away and repeat the process with your own data/details.  You will be provided with comprehensive course notes to enable you to update the case study information with your own information. 
At each step, key considerations and financial concepts will be defined, explained and discussed to help you understand the financial requirements of retirement.  
Are you ready for the retirement lifestyle you hoped or dreamed of?  If not, then this course is for you.
[A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Disclaimer:  The tutors are not financial advisors.  No investments, products nor specific recommendations will be provided.  A step by step planning process will be taught by working through a case study.  Key considerations that should be used by the participants when looking at their own options to bridge the financial gap between what is available through superannuation and what is required to meet lifestyle goals will be provided and discussed.  Product names may be used in examples and explanations to help participants understand the financial concepts and the planning process.

We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Are you a computer slouch, feeling stiff and tense at work? Do you find it difficult to maintain a good posture?  Does your posture cause back, neck or shoulder tension?  Would you like to enjoy more freedom in everyday activities?
Under the guidance of an experienced teacher, we'll explore movement in ways that help you reduce tense unhelpful habits.  Movement lessons are done on the floor or sitting on a chair and are based on the pioneering work of Israeli physicist and engineer Dr. Moshe Feldenkrais.
This workshop is suitable for all ages (over 16) and fitness levels.
By the end of the workshop, you'll be able to:
• Identify and reduce muscle tension
• Move with more lightness and freedom
• Improve your posture
• Describe some basic anatomy
• Have tools to use at home and at work
Bring two blankets (or a mat and a blanket) and wear loose, warm and comfortable clothing. Tea and coffee provided but bring your lunch. Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required.

Mental Health First Aid is an evidence-based workshop which gives people the skills and confidence to have supportive conversations with their whānau, co-workers and community and help guide them to professional help if needed.
You will learn to recognise common mental health challenges, how to provide initial help to someone experiencing a mental health challenge using a practical, evidence-based action plan, and how to respond in a crisis situation. Depression
Anxiety
Psychosis
Substance use problems
Mental Health Crisis Covered:
Suicidal thoughts and behaviours
Non- Suicidal self-injury
Panic attack
Traumatic events
Severe effects from Alcohol or other substance use
Aggressive behaviours
People who attend Mental Health First Aid training can complete a short online assessment to be accredited as a Mental Health First Aider. You must attend the full two days to be able to do the online assessment for accreditation. The accreditation is valid for three years.

description:
Retirement Reinvented
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
In your middle years, working, retired or somewhere in between? What’s next? Life is about much more than work or leisure, but most of us have given little thought to what “retirement” might mean.
It’s difficult to speculate what may happen in the future – but we can be proactive and take control.
This course offers insights into how to make the most of our time once we’re less focused on career and/or childrearing. It covers many of the issues people face when considering a move from current employment to a different lifestyle that includes more time to do the things we’ve always promised ourselves we’d do – “when we retire”.
After the workshop, you’ll be able to identify a number of common issues and potential ways to manage them when considering and planning your “rejuvenation”, rather than a retirement. We won’t cover financial planning, but will focus on some of the personal growth opportunities for living and making a conscious contribution to your community.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
By the end of the day, you’ll have:
Developed your own perspective on ageing and retirement in the 21st Century and identified what’s important to you
Completed a personal life audit exercise and considered your values and your strengths
Considered options to include a sense of purpose and explore choices that can provide you with that sense of purpose
Explored possibilities in the major aspects of your life and identified potential challenges and strategies for overcoming them
Begun to develop your blueprint to maximise the best years of your life and have considered a “future proofing” downsizing plan.
Bring pen and paper.

This workshop will be a confronting one that will expose you to the risks that children face in this modern overindulgent world. Many have become used to being the constant centre of attention and are unable to delay gratification and aren’t competent in everyday skills. They have few self-care skills and skills relating to others, can’t take personal responsibility and don’t know what is enough or what is “normal” for others – these children end up having a difficult time of it in life and you will too.
 You’ll take away new insight and knowledge plus strategies that you can apply that very night to help your child to be a responsible, likeable and respectful person.

This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
An interactive workshop presented by experienced physiotherapist Sara Dore, focusing on how movement and function can be challenging for women as they age. Particularly for women, there is more to the core than abdominal muscles and strength and we explore these broader aspects.  Most importantly, you will come to understand that movement is medicine and we can make a difference.
You will be able to make a positive difference for yourself! The objective of this workshop is to give you knowledge and understanding about how you can manage the effects on your health and wellbeing as we age as women.  Knowledge is power!
In this one-day workshop you will discover:
- The base of the pelvic floor. Anatomy of the pelvic floor, and the common conditions urinary incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse will be discussed. Education on basic pelvic floor advice and management as well as appropriate exercises will also be covered.
- The middle deep abdominal muscles. Trunk stability versus core strength as we age and the impact on our other core muscles and pelvic floor will be discussed. The principles of Clinical Pilates versus traditional Pilates will be presented together with the key principles of movement is medicine.
-The importance of the diaphragm and breathing well will also be discussed to enhance optimal movement and function for women.
Please wear comfortable clothes and socks as this is an interactive workshop, and bring a yoga mat or beach towel.
Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch and snacks.

Meet the demand for excellence in the job market head on. Learn how to utilise the STARR technique in the way that recruiters use it. That is, to define and seek out the skills and qualities of the best candidate. Master the STARR skills and feel confident in your next job interview.

description:
Mindfulness Meditation
Meditation can help us with life’s challenges and is a wise way to work with strong emotions and stress, as well as enlivening the ordinary times. It’s simple and doesn’t need any special resources. Often learning to meditate is presented as something esoteric and mysterious but really it should be a straightforward thing based on our everyday experience.
Come along to this course and learn how to put a meditation practice in place in your life. You’ll be introduced to some different meditation and mindfulness techniques and get an insight into the modern psychology and the ancient wisdom that supports a meditation practice.
The four sessions will provide time to practise different styles of meditation, lots of hints about a fruitful approach to take to set up a regular practice in your life and opportunities to discuss progress with others in the group.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Describe some ways in which modern psychology and ancient wisdom support meditation
Understand what you need to do to make time for meditation in your life
Describe practical tips to make meditation fruitful
Practise different kinds of guided and silent meditation
Find resources (books, on-line information, other classes and retreats) to support your meditation

description:
Qi Gong
Qigong has both psychological and physical components and involves the regulation of the mind, breath, and body’s movement and posture.
In most forms of qigong:
Breath is slow, long, and deep. Breath patterns may switch from abdominal breathing to breathing combined with speech sounds.
Movements are typically gentle and smooth, aimed for relaxation.
Mind regulation includes focusing one’s attention and visualization.
Dynamic (active) qigong techniques primarily focus on body movements, especially movements of the whole body or arms and legs. Meditative (passive) qigong techniques can be practiced in any posture that can be maintained over time and involve breath and mind exercises, with almost no body movement.

id: Self-Hypnosis - Hypnotise Yourself-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Self-Hypnosis - Hypnotise Yourself
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Self-Hypnosis - Hypnotise Yourself
Self-hypnosis is a fantastic self-development tool. It can also be used for controlling pain, accelerated healing, letting go of limiting behaviours and a number of other applications. This workshop will provide you with a good insight into the world of hypnosis, demystify it and dispel the myths that surround it.
You’ll learn a structured method of taking yourself into hypnosis (informed by scientific research), some of the classic applications of self-hypnosis and evidence-based skills that will convince you without doubt of your ability to hypnotise yourself.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
• Define and discuss hypnosis
• Practice self-hypnosis
• Create and write hypnosis scripts for personal change
• Use the language of self-hypnosis
• Relax hypnotically to deep levels
Tea and coffee provided but bring your lunch, pen and paper.

name: Beekeeping - Next Step
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Beekeeping - Next Step
This is a practical and hands-on experience so bring your beekeeper’s outfit and your lunch. Please check your course instructions for more information on what you need to bring on the day.  The tutor can lend you a veil if you don't have one, please let the CEC office know a week before the course is due to run so this can be arranged.
The workshop starts in the classroom and is followed by a visit to a local apiary.  (Please note that you will working with live bees during the visit so there is a chance of being stung by one.)
If weather isn't suitable on the day, the morning session will still go ahead but the visit will be postponed to the next available Saturday.   Please note that if you can't make the catch-up visit, it's not possible to join in later courses due to number restrictions (a part-refund will be made). You must have done the Beginners' course first.
By the end of the workshop, you'll be able to:
• List the key steps in setting up a hive
• Describe how honey is extracted
• State what causes swarming and some ways of preventing it
• Describe what needs to be done to manage Varoa and American Foul Brood 
• Construct kitset frames for a honey super
• Open up and inspect a hive

id: Songwriting: How to Write Your Own Songs-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Songwriting: How to Write Your Own Songs
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Songwriting: How to Write Your Own Songs
The course is ideal for anyone who wants to write better songs - whether you’ve got a few songs under your belt or you’re a complete beginner. Take a song idea through to a finished song you can be proud of. Split into easy-to-follow steps, this course walks you through everything from finding titles to writing chord progressions and ensuring your lyrics and melodies fit together. You’ll share your creations with fellow songwriters and get personalised feedback. You’ll see exactly how to turn theory into practice and write your best songs yet.
This course includes:
-  Practical tips and techniques for songwriting
-  Ideas for making your songs stronger, more expressive and more appealing to your audience
-  How to overcome writer’s block, be an inspired and prolific songwriter who writes authentic songs
-  An opportunity to share your songs with fellow students, bounce off ideas and learn from one another
-  Learn how to structure a song effectively
-  The pillars of songwriting and how to use them
-  How to write better lyrics
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-  Discover the exact steps to successfully write your own original songs; expanding a song from a verse and chorus, to a complete song while keeping your listeners engaged using transitions and dynamic contrasts between sections
-  Come up with ideas, write lyrics, melodies, chord progressions and instrumental grooves that have an emotional impact on you and your audience
-  Identify the structure of a great song, including how to combine melody, chords, lyrics and rhythm that create magic for your listeners
-  Possess the confidence and skills to find inspiration and get past common creative hurdles and blocks so you can develop an initial spark of creativity into a complete song
-  Stay inspired and find your authentic voice as a songwriter. r

venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
The Joy of Improvisation
Improv is theatre without a script and a fun way to build your skills in many areas, including team work, public speaking, storytelling and on-your-feet creative thinking.
This is the perfect place for absolute beginners to get acquainted with the joy and art of improvisation, inspired by the generous creative philosophy of Keith Johnstone. It's also a great place to get back into improv if you've been away from it for a while.
WIT has been teaching this course in association with the CEC for almost 20 years now. It uses fun games and structured exercises to teach the foundation skills of improv. These are a prerequisite for further courses and membership of WIT (www.wit.org.nz), as well as useful in themselves.
If you have questions about the course, please contact WIT directly on info@wit.org.nz.
By the end of the course, you'll have: 
• Explored basic principles of improvisation
• Enjoyed interacting in a friendly, positive and supportive environment
• Developed more confidence, presentation and communication skills
• Experienced joyful moments of improvisation
The course will end with a directed demonstration of class exercises for invited friends and family.

Dare to Be Seen – Overcome Stage Fright and Performance Anxiety
The skills you will practice may be applied to presentations, interviews, appraisals, business meetings, networking, performing on stage and more. Prepare yourself to deliver your best self under pressure. Discover the art of being seen and heard.
 Learn how to banish stage fright and performance anxiety. Communicate from a place of confidence and energy. Hold the room and speak with authority. Come across authentically, with maximum personal impact.
In this masterclass we will work with the fundamental toolkit of each person’s body, breath, voice and mindset to increase communicative power, gravitas and influence. You will leave with the skills to master any kind of performance you need to give.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-  Understand how your physical, mental and vocal habits help you or hinder your effectiveness
-  Practice simple repeatable exercises that will transform your capacity to make a powerful entrance
-  Learn how to manage nerves, take up space and land your message with impact.

name: How to be a DJ - An Introduction
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
How to be a DJ - An Introduction
Always wanted to try being a DJ but not sure where to begin? Experienced and professional DJ Shan (Shannon Chng-Rawiri) will teach you all about the technical aspects, equipment and terminology, as well as the industry in general, and enable you to put together a confident short performance.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Gain an understanding of the work content and career opportunities in this industry
Learn the difference between what a DJ is required to deliver in the following situations: Mobile, Club, Radio, Turntablist and Hobby
Participate in various practical activities: Slip Cueing and Baby Scratch, basic beat matching and song structures
Gain a good understanding of the equipment used and terminology including: - Tables: pitch control - Mixer: crossfader, input faders, EQ, gain, cue system - Needles: back tracking - Slip Mats
Learn about Counting Bars and Matching Tempos - The difference between a Bar, Phrases and BPM - Techniques to Count, Hand position and movement etc
Confidently present a 5 minute performance in class
The course will be held at DJ Shan’s studio at Shop 21, 73 Cuba Street, Wellington.  Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.

id: Scottish Country Dancing-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Scottish Country Dancing
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Scottish Country Dancing
Why do Scottish Country Dancing? Great music and amazing ‘brain gym’ for body and mind! Scottish Country Dancing is a very social form of dancing, danced in "sets" usually with four "couples" - unlike Highland Dancing which is usually solo dancing. Have fun and meet new people, while getting fit!
It’s suitable for all levels of fitness, and is a great way of meeting and socialising with new people. Scottish country dancing is a common pastime for thousands of dancers in many countries, whether you’re in Japan, Germany, the US or Scotland itself.
Wear soft flat shoes and loose clothing and bring a bottle of water. No partner is needed – we change partners for every dance!
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Name and perform to beginner level the five major steps of Scottish Country Dancing
• Name and perform ten simple formations
• Participate in five simple Scottish Country dances, in strathspey (slow) and reel/jig (fast) tempo
• Clap rhythm to reel, jig and strathspey tempo
• Have the confidence and skills to join a club to progress your social dancing

name: Acing The Interview
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Acing The Interview
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
People have skills which they want to offer to employers, however, low confidence and anxiety combined with a lack of interview experience results in them not gaining employment.
'Acing The Interview' is a 3-module one day workshop that provides practical, cutting-edge tools and techniques to prepare participants to 'Ace the Interview'.
The 3 modules are:
1. Resourceful You - Think
2. Managing You - Feel
3. Acing the Interview - Do
Explore how to manage your thoughts under pressure and control your critical voice. Understand how to manage anxiety and stress. Demonstrate your interview skills and use body language and well-formed responses to create a powerful and positive first impression.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-  Manage your thoughts and critical voice under pressure
-  Visualise and mentally rehearse for success
-  Recognise your emotional reactions and manage your emotions under pressure
-  Utilise techniques to manage anxiety
-  Demonstrate interview skills and deliver well-formed responses to questions
-  Understand the STAR model and other communication techniques and how and when to use them

name: Social Media Marketing for Small Enterprises: Visual Impact
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Social Media Marketing for Small Enterprises: Visual Impact
Whether you are just starting out or already running a business, having an online and social media presence is essential. While most of us know in theory that we need a marketing plan, a social media strategy, a consistent post schedule, and engaging reels for TikTok, the reality is that every business is unique, and your approach should reflect that.
 One constant across all online presences is the importance of visuals—photographs, images, and graphics. With attention spans shorter than ever, your audience will move on within seconds if they are not engaged—they see images first and then only start reading the text. If you can't captivate their attention, you risk losing potential customers. Generic and overused stock images, or AI-generated visuals, can do more harm than good, even if they seem like an affordable option.
 In this course, we will explore different types of content suitable for your specific needs and audiences, how to create it or where to source it, how to develop the right visual strategy for your online presence, what tools to use, and how to implement it immediately. By the end of the course, you will have an outstanding online presence.
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo id when you attend the workshop.
 By the end of the four-week course, you’ll be able to:
 Recognise the critical role of visuals in social media marketing.
Choose the most effective type of visual content for your brand.
Produce high-quality, engaging visuals using various tools and techniques.
Implement a cohesive visual strategy across multiple social media platforms.
Assess and refine your visual strategy to maximise engagement and build trust with your audience.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. id: Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
name: Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
description:
Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Explore how to appropriately structure and polish your CV and cover letter in order to achieve optimum results. This course prioritises you. Identify your key skills and weave these into your CV and cover letter to land you your next job interview.
 Whatever job you are going for, there are key characteristics that should not be missed in your CV and cover letter. The focus of this course is to provide you with the same lens as a recruiter. By learning how your job application is reviewed by a recruiter, you will gain skills to streamline your CV, and improve your cover letter writing. This will increase your chances of being a successful candidate and sets you up to land an interview for your ideal job.
 It doesn’t matter what previous experience you have - everyone has a range of skills that they can offer to their future employer. Fortunately, a strong and realistic CV and cover letter will showcase these skills and increase your chances for job success.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Recognise the features of an effective, well-crafted CV and cover letter and apply these to your own job applications;
- Apply different approaches, styles and techniques while writing your CV and cover letter depending on the context and job;
- Help others with their CV and cover letter writing (friends and whānau).
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
 Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
